trans-unit.source: Represents a cryptographic object identifier.
This class cannot be inherited.
Cryptographic object identifiers consist of a value/name pair.
If one property in a pair is set to a known value, the other property is updated automatically to a corresponding value.

For example, if the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.Value%2A> property is set to "1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.4", the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.FriendlyName%2A> property, which is localized, is set automatically to "Secure Email".
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> class.
This is the default constructor.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> class using the specified <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> object.
This constructor copies the values of an existing <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> object to a new object.
The object identifier information to use to create the new object identifier.
oid is `null`.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> class using a string value of an <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> object.
This constructor copies the values of an existing <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> object to a new object.
An object identifier.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> class using the specified value and friendly name.
This constructor can be used to copy the values of an existing <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> object.
Note that if the Oid value is not recognized, the `value` and `friendlyName` parameters are not verified to determine if they correspond to each other.
This is because there are object identifiers that the .NET Framework does not recognize, although an application may be able to interpret them.
The dotted number of the identifier.
The friendly name of the identifier.
Gets or sets the friendly name of the identifier.

If one value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is set to a known value, the other value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is updated automatically to a corresponding value.

For example, if the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.FriendlyName%2A> property is set to "Secure Email", the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.Value%2A> property is set automatically to "1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.4".
The friendly name of the identifier.
Creates an <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> object from an OID friendly name by searching the specified group.
The friendly name of the identifier.
The group to search in.
An object that represents the specified OID.
friendlyName is `null`.
The OID was not found.
Creates an <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> object by using the specified OID value and group.
The OID value.
The group to search in.
A new instance of an <xref href="System.Security.Cryptography.Oid"></xref> object.
oidValue is `null`.
The friendly name for the OID value was not found.
Gets or sets the dotted number of the identifier.

If one value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is set to a known value, the other value of an <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid> property is updated automatically to a corresponding value.

For example, if the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.Value%2A> property is set to "1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.4", the <xref:System.Security.Cryptography.Oid.FriendlyName%2A> property is set automatically to "Secure Email".
The dotted number of the identifier.
